name: Can We Talk About Pale Masters?
author: Fist

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Apart from the vaguely racist, slavey, name, I know next to nothing about this class. I read the wiki page, and could see the AC benefits (bear in mind my preference for melee-types), bards being able to take epic spells (though I'm unclear how that works in practice), and the increase in spell slot numbers, but it's this last one that brings me to my first question.

What's the point in heavy investment in PM levels when you'll just have more crappy spells to cast? Surely  you need to be able to cast some higher levels spells before more slots becomes advantageous?

Also, are their summons any use, or can a decent cleric/ pally/ arcanist/ and even ranger with a FE in undeads just blow 'em away, or even a simple grunt knock 'em into next week?

Oh, and are they INT or CHA casters, or does that depend on their "mother" class?

Let's start with those three, though I imagine there will be more questions later. I've never played or built one (well, I did, but it was a kind of joke character from "Kings of the Wyld"), and we are sadly lacking in a Guide to the class here (which reminds me, I promised to draw up a CoT Guide about 150 years ago - someone prod me if it's still not forthcoming by March, eh?).

Inquiring minds need to know!

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
PM is a PrC that is often used (10 levels) to impart immunity to Crits and SA.  For most, that's where it ends.

PM, however, is more, as it will also grant some pretty good AC bonuses as well.  And, as you have mentioned, there is the 15 levels of PM that grant Epic Spell capability (re: selection).  As to why, it's because of this
all spellcasting classes capable of casting ninth level spells can learn how to cast them.
Pale Master requires a spellcaster that can cast 3rd level spells, so 3+1/2 of 15= 9th level spells, this is the reason, basically.

It is the only way for a Bard to get Epic Spells without going Sorc/Wizard etc, as they "only" get 6th level spells max.

The Pale Master is NOT implimented properly from the PnP source material, unfortunately.  It is supposed to ALSO advance Caster Level (1/2 Pale Master levels), but for whatever reason, Bioware did not impliment this.  Also, Pale Masters should allow for spell selection when their corresponding spellcasting Class gets them (something that Bioware also did not impliment).

For the most part, the best combination (besides the above mentioned Bard) is Wizard, because Wizards can get new spells from scrolls, allowing them use of higher spellslots through PM levels.  Other Classes (Arcane only) can only do this through meta-magical means, which is subpaar.

The Deathless Master Touch should NOT be underestimated!  It starts at DC 17 fortitude save and the DC is raised by 1 for every 2 levels past 10th.  It is a touch attack, and it totally slays anything that is not immune to death or has a low Fort save (like spellcasters).

As for the summons...well, the vanilla summons are super meh.  I really do not know how a PM summons (like a Demilich) performs in an SP environment, and I am sure that in a low magic environment, they might actually perform somewhat, but for any other environment, they absolutely suck.  Yes, I know that is a strong thing to say, but experience shows that this is true.  Even on WoG, where they have been buffed, they still SUCK!

YMMV

P.S. We should have more of these types of deep dives into different Classes imo!  Great stuff, Stag.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
I agree with Web on this one!
Both the PM and RDD classes were introduced as prestige classes for spellcasters. However, they failed at that and their main use in power builds is for melee characters.
PM offers a serious boost to AC and gets immunity to crits at level 10. It is a great way to defend against devastating critical.
At PM level 15 the character can start taking epic spells, no level 9 spell casting needed.
Primary saving throws are fortitude and will. That can be beneficial for some builds, but be careful and don't take too many levels pre epic with the 1/2 BAB progression of the PM class.
For casters, you get extra spell slots and access to new spell levels at half the normal rate. Wizards can read up on spells and learn higher level spells that way. Sorcerers and bards can use the higher level slots for meta magic.
The big problem with PM casters is that the caster level does not scale with PM levels. There has been much talk about fixing this, but I do not know the current status.

I have a build where I also use PM for it's class skills. It is a Wizard10/ PM2/ Assassin28, where I take the first PM level at character level 5 to benefit from the Hide and Move silently class skills of the PM class to qualify for Assassin at level 6.
The build has Int 16 and can learn level 6 spells with only 10 wizard levels because of the slots from PM.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
GDL has really shown us how PM can be a great part of a build, focusing on Damage shields, a high constitution and EDR. Fighter offers feats galore for EDR, and PM offers immunities, while you still have reasonably high Wizard levels with indispellability and a fair spell penetration. I really like the concept!

On the other hand, the PM class has had success as part of melee builds with a high AC, immunity to dev crit and sneak-/death attacks, and even offering epic spells. Most often these builds are based on bard to qualify for PM and also providing important class skills, such as tumble, discipline, listen, spellcraft and UMD. Then there are the songs! 
Fighter and Blackguard are popular classes to bring to the mix with full BAB and their weapon, armor and shield proficiencies.

Okay, some of us learn by theory, some by practice, and some of us by demonstrating where our failings lie and asking for help. That latter would be me.

So, something Mick mentioned earlier about PM and RDD both being PRCs that benefited melee builds more than caster ones (by and large), so I thought "why not sew the two together - and in a fairly extreme way". So I have, and the results are below. Please note, I have not included this in the Build Request forum and that is because it's purely experimental in nature (unless, ofc, you like it, in which case I'll move it). I wanted it to be as purely melee-based as possible (given that it requires at least 3 levels of caster - well 5 in this case - and has 2 "supernatural" classes baked in), so no damage shields, acid sheaths, epic warding, etc. Just a sturdy fellow whose whole purpose is to block doors, bridges, vision, drains, and so forth. Admittedly, a DwD would be my normal go-to here, but I wanted to experiment.

posts.author: Theophilus Fist
posts.content:
I was stuck in a hotel room with COVID-19 and my iPad while I quarantined, so I figured I would make a "no-brainer" build - one I didn't have to think about leveling.  First 3 lvls Bard, 2 lvls PM, 10 lvls RDD and then the rest PM except for Bard Tumble dumps at 27 & 37.  Strength build with a spear.  Only 3 APR, but decent AB, high AC, high HP, immune to almost everything and casts Epic Spells.  I had no problems taking him to 40 as a tank in SOU/HOTU/SoF.

He's almost impossible to kill.
